summary: The documents provided are primarily payroll and certification reports from the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). These reports detail the salaries, positions, and pay period earnings of the committee's employees. The reports span from 1977 to 1979, covering various accounting periods. They list employee names, social security numbers, positions within the committee, annual salaries, and gross pay for specific periods. The documents serve as official records of the financial administration of the HSCA, providing a detailed account of how taxpayer money was allocated to staff members during the investigation into the JFK assassination.
key_connections: Employees of the Select Committee on Assassinations
significance: The salaries are significant as they represent the financial resources allocated to the HSCA's investigation into the JFK assassination. The payroll records provide transparency into the staffing and operational costs of the committee. While the salaries themselves don't directly solve the assassination, they are part of the broader context of the investigation, showing the resources dedicated to uncovering the truth.
